entry.title: Re: How to properly save/post in EWM table /SCWM/HUHDR gi...
entry.content: Hi, I solved it. For the Inbound Delivery-HU mapping, get data from table /scwm/huref comparing fields docid and doccat. To maintain data in HU Header, first lock the HU with static method /scwm/cl_pack=>lock_hu, then call function module '/SCWM/HUHEADER_READ' to read the corresponding HU structure, and maintain the fields you want if success, and then update it via function module '/SCWM/HUHDR_INT_UPDATE'. Then the fields are now updated in the standard table.

entry.title: Re: Material Staging concept
entry.content:
Dear @Ibrahim_Samir47,

In Public Cloud material staging is the internal replenishment step that makes sure production components are physically and system-wise available at the issue point (production storage location / Production Supply Area) before you post the goods issue (GI 261) to the production order for consumption

What material staging means:

  • When a production order is created, SAP creates reservations for its BOM components
  • Very often, components are stored in a central warehouse/storage location, while the shop floor uses a different production storage location. So you first need to move/stage the components from the supply location to the production/issue location
  • That move to the shop floor is what SAP calls material staging, it’s not yet consumption

More details below:

https://learning.sap.com/courses/implementing-sap-s-4hana-cloud-public-edition-manufacturing/executing-production-orders_eebd35c8-b7ed-4f36-bd4a-fb527dfa1322

There are two often-confused GI „moments”:

1. GI for staging (replenishment / transfer posting)
This is the posting that finishes staging by transferring stock to the production storage location / PSA often via delivery/warehouse execution if WM is involved. In delivery-based production integration, once staging is completed GI is posted for the outbound delivery and the components are transferred to the production storage location and become available for consumption

2. GI to the production order (GI 261- consumption)
This is the real consumption posting that reduces inventory and posts the component cost to the production order. In Public Cloud you can do this:

    • Manually for example Post Goods Movement / Pick Components for Production Orders or
    • Automatically (backflush) during confirmations for example Confirm Production Order / Confirm Production Order Operation

More details below:

https://learning.sap.com/courses/implementing-sap-s-4hana-cloud-public-edition-warehouse-management/introducing-warehouse-production-integration_e54cb620-bcb1-4567-a55d-50ad2d2cc7c9

https://learning.sap.com/courses/implementing-sap-s-4hana-cloud-public-edition-warehouse-management/integrating-sap-s-4hana-private-cloud-sap-ewm-production-integration-processes_c3a2e7ad-262f-49d3-ad0d-368099b3f8ff

https://fioriappslibrary.hana.ondemand.com/sap/fix/externalViewer/#/detail/Apps('MIGO')/S35

https://fioriappslibrary.hana.ondemand.com/sap/fix/externalViewer/#/detail/Apps('CO27')/S35

https://fioriappslibrary.hana.ondemand.com/sap/fix/externalViewer/#/detail/Apps('CO11N')/S35

https://fioriappslibrary.hana.ondemand.com/sap/fix/externalViewer/#/detail/Apps('CO11N')/S35

Common staging approaches in Public Cloud:

  • Pull list / stock transfer staging moves required components from central storage to the production storage location so GI/backflush can happen from there
  • Kanban replenishment is triggered when containers are emptied it keeps small quantities available at production
  • Delivery-based staging with Warehouse Management / EWM integration staging creates an outbound delivery / outbound delivery order warehouse tasks move goods to the PSA and GI for the delivery finalizes the transfer to production storage

More details below:

https://learning.sap.com/courses/implementing-sap-s-4hana-cloud-public-edition-warehouse-management/introducing-warehouse-production-integration_e54cb620-bcb1-4567-a55d-50ad2d2cc7c9

Summary:

  • Staging = make it available at the shop floor (logistics / replenishment control)
  • Goods issue to the production order = used it in production (consumption and costing)

Best Regards,

Dawid

entry.title: Turning SAP BTP Integration Suite as a core ERP module for Business APIs & Business AI
entry.content:
ERP modernization is not enough

Over recent years, SAP clients have concentrated transformation efforts on S/4HANA to standardize processes, adopt cloud operating models (public, private, hybrid, sovereign), and enable continuous evolution. In parallel, the integration backbone must evolve from SAP PI-PO to SAP Integration Suite, ensuring your enterprise can operate API‑first and Event‑first, at the speed and scale modern business demands.

  • Context: SAP PI/PO maintenance aligns with NetWeaver 7.5 lifecycles. But this decision point is not just about end‑of‑maintenance.
  • Imperative: Integration modernization is foundational to agility, AI‑enabled processes, and resilient cloud operations across heterogeneous landscapes.

Beyond “middleware”: What SAP Integration Suite really is

SAP Integration Suite is not a one‑to‑one PI-PO replacement. It’s an enterprise iPaaS on SAP BTP that unifies:

  • Cloud Integration for process and data integration
  • API Management to design, secure, publish, and govern Business APIs
  • Event Mesh for event‑driven architectures (EDA)
  • Integration Advisor and content packages for accelerated build
  • Monitoring and observability for end‑to‑end visibility across hybrid landscapes

This shift, from “interfaces” to "Business APIs", enables secure, discoverable, measurable, and even monetizable capabilities. It opens a path to Composable Architecture, where SAP and non‑SAP modules can be assembled, re‑assembled, and composed to meet changing business needs.

Key benefits:

  • Speed: Faster delivery via reusable APIs, events, and prebuilt content
  • Quality: Strong governance, testing patterns, and observability
  • Resilience: Decoupling through asynchronous events and queues
  • Scale & Security: Unified policy enforcement, rate limiting, and consistent identity/access models

From Monolith to Modular: Real‑Time, Composable Integration

For Supply Chain, Manufacturing, and other data‑intensive domains, real‑time integration is essential. By slicing the SAP monolith into modular building blocks, organizations can distribute, elevate, and govern data across the enterprise and partners ecosystem.

  • Decoupled communication allows plug‑and‑play assembly of new components and systems.
  • Event‑driven patterns (domain events, queues, fan‑out) reduce coupling and improve reliability.
  • Business APIs + events become the operating surface for cross‑system processes and innovation.

Preparing for Enterprise AI Agents: Event‑First, API‑First

AI is rapidly moving beyond chat into agents that act, use tools, and orchestrate work across systems. SAP is rolling out agentic capabilities on SAP BTP, including Joule Studio for Enterprise Agents, and secure access to foundation models via SAP AI Core and Generative AI Hub. Capabilities and patterns emerging in the ecosystem include:

  • Model Context Protocol (MCP) to simplify agent connections to tools and data
  • Agent‑to‑Agent (A2A) patterns/protocols for secure, autonomous collaboration
  • AI Adapter patterns to link Integration Suite flows with GenAI tasks

In this operating model, Business APIs and events let agents subscribe to near real‑time signals, trigger actions/approvals, and enrich processes, reusing the IT estate and preserving existing investments while modernizing how work gets done.

A Practical PI-PO to Integration Suite Path

Treat the transformation as a program, not a lift‑and‑shift. A pragmatic path often includes:

  1. Assessment & Prioritization

    • Inventory interfaces (by business process, domain, criticality, volume, latency).
    • Identify patterns: synchronous APIs, asynchronous events, B2B/EDI, file, IDoc, RFC, REST/SOAP.

  2. Target Architecture & Design Principles

    • Define API‑first and event‑first standards (naming, versioning, domain event taxonomy).
    • Establish security models (identity, scopes, policies), observability, and SLAs.

  3. Co‑Existence & Strangler Pattern

    • Run PI-PO and Integration Suite side by side.
    • Gradually redirect traffic to new APIs/events, decommission legacy interfaces incrementally.

  4. Enablement & Guardrails

  5. Cutover & Stabilization

  6. Decommissioning & Continuous Evolution

    • Retire redundant PI-PO objects; codify lessons learned.
    • Expand event domains; evolve API products; onboard partners faster.

Anti‑Patterns to avoid

  • Lift‑and‑shift without rethinking business APIs and event domains
  • Point‑to‑point proliferation that undermines modularity and reuse
  • No product ownership, leaving integrations to drift without roadmaps or SLAs
  • Limited observability, making troubleshooting slow and costly

The takeaway

The ECC to S/4HANA journey modernizes the core.
The PI-PO to Integration Suite journey operationalizes Business APIs and events, enabling composable architectures, resilient integrations, and AI‑ready operating models.

Organizations that treat integration as a business platform - rather than a technical migration - will gain a durable advantage in agility, innovation, and speed to value.

Call to Action

Are you aligning the PI-PO to Integration Suite transformation with your Cloud ERP journey? Start with a portfolio assessment, define API‑first and event‑first standards, and establish a co‑existence plan that drives measurable business outcomes. The sooner you begin, the faster your enterprise will be ready for event‑driven processes and AI agents.

entry.title: SAP Public Cloud 2508 / Issues during the Maintenance of Partner Roles for Business Partners
entry.content:
Hello Experts,

i have the following question for the maintenance of partner functions with the app "maintain business partner master data".
My Scenario is the following, i have a Business partner with the BP-Role "customer" and i have a BP with the BP-Role "contact person".
I want to assign this contact person to a custom partner function for this customer. When i go to the section partner roles in the sales area data of the customer, i can create a new entry with the custom partner function and then i have to select the business partner. 

At this point its important to mention that the system is customized in way, that this partner function only accepts contact persons as entries. So the BP with the BP role contact person has to have a contact person relationship and this relationship has a number assigned to it, which the SAP System reffers to as the "Partner number" (PARNR).

This number now has to be selected, when i want to assign the partner role and not the BP number that the contact person has.

If i want to do this in the older App/Transaction "BP" i cant just go to the partner role section and for the selection of the BP, i can filter the list to only those relationships that are related to this Customer.

BUT if i want to do the same thing in the new App, i have to know the exact number of the relationship, because the app displays all relationships for all customers and i cant filter it in the same way.
The second issue is, that the Partner number i need to know, is also not displayed in the section "contact persons" in the customer or enywhere else and only the BP number of this contact person is displayed there.
As a result the only solutions i have found so far are, to use the Transaction "BP" or to use a custom CDS View to view the "partner number".

My question is, is this the standard behavoir ? Is there no way to filter the realtionships in a same way as in the Transaction BP ? Is there a standard way to display the "Partner number" in the app "Manage Business Partner Master Data", or do i need to create a custom field ?

Im greatfull for all answers and tipps.
Best regards
Lukas

entry.title: BW on HANA →BW PCE (Lift & Shift): realistic split of SAP vs customer/partner Basis responsibilities
entry.content:
Hi all,

We are requested to support a BW on HANA 7.5 migration / lift to the private cloud edition.

I recently attended an SAP webinar about SAP Business Data Cloud and BW Private Cloud Edition. During the Q&A, I asked about the typical split of responsibilities and effort between SAP AG Basis and customer/partner Basis during a lift & shift migration of BW on HANA 7.5 to BW 7.5 PCE.

The answer was roughly “~70% SAP AG Basis, ~30% customer”, but the presenter also mentioned this was more of a rough estimate.

I would be interested in hearing practical project experiences from the community:

  • Which activities are typically handled by SAP AG (beyond infrastructure and system copy)?

  • Which activities realistically remain with the customer or a partner (e.g. preparation, cleanup, user/role validation, testing, cutover coordination)?

  • In projects where the customer had limited or no PCE experience, how important was a partner Basis/BW role to bridge the gap?

  • Does it suffice to plan for 1 Clinent / Partner Basis resource + 1 SAP AG Basis + 1 BW resource?
  • How long does it take to move a 3 tier BW system having ca. 2 TB in prod into the cloud targetting for only a 2-tier landscape (QA/DEV together and PROD)
  • Did you face any major issues with connections to other systems, performance, process chains, queries/ reports, roles / access after the lift to PCE?

Thanks in advance for sharing your experience.

entry.title: Reset development object to SAP standard
entry.content:
Hi,

unfortunately we have several modifications in SAP development object using the SAP modification assistant.

We want to remove some of these modifications to switch back to the SAP default implementation.

The only way (that I know) to do this is by using transaction SPAU and reset the object to SAP.
In this case not only the code will reset to SAP implementation, the field "last changed by user" will be set to SAP aswell.
According to my experience so far, especially this field "last changed by user" of an object is the reason, if an object will be shown up during SPAU or not.

Is there any other way to reset a modified development object to SAP default?

If I simply remove the modifications, this only affects the code but not the field "last changed by user".

BR

entry.title: Fit-to-Standard Strategy for SFG Stock Consumption and PIR Reduction by Dependent Requirements
entry.content:
Problem Description:
We are seeking the correct Fit-to-Standard planning strategy in S/4HANA Public Cloud 2026 for a multi-level manufacturing scenario. Current testing with Strategies 10, 40 and 70 has not fulfilled all business requirements simultaneously.

 

Business Requirements:

  1. Stock Priority: The system must check and use available warehouse stock before triggering new planned orders.
  2. Dual Demand Consumption: Planned Independent Requirements (PIRs) for the SFG must be consumed by both:
    • Direct Sales Orders for the SFG.
    • Dependent Requirements triggered by FG production.
    • No Duplicate Planning: If a forecast (PIR) exists for 100 units and a Dependent Requirement for 40 units arrives, the system should only plan for a total of 100 units (60 PIR + 40 DepReq), not 140.

      Example Scenario for Analysis:

      • Material: SFG_001
      • Initial Stock: 20 EA
      • PIR (Requirement Type VSFB): 100 EA for Date X
      • New Requirement: FG order creates a Dependent Requirement of 50 EA for Date X.
      • Expected Result:
        • Dependent Requirement (50) consumes PIR (100), leaving 50 remaining PIR.
        • MRP sees total requirement (50 DepReq + 50 remaining PIR = 100 total).
        • MRP subtracts Stock (20) and creates a Planned Order for 80 EA
        • Observed Result in Starter System: MRP is creating separate orders for both PIR and Dependent Requirements, ignoring consumption logic.

           

          Please confirm the standard Strategy Group and Mixed MRP indicator combination for the 2026 release that enables PIR consumption by Dependent Requirements specifically for sub assemblies.

          # SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Manufacturing

entry.title: Re: Can I block invoice automatically if material not rec...
entry.content:
Dear @Gavara,

Yes you can automatically block or even prevent a supplier invoice when the goods receipt (GR) hasn’t been posted for the PO item

Option 1: GR-based Invoice Verification on the PO

If the PO item is set to GR-based invoice verification, invoices are verified against delivered quantities GRs. In practice the invoice quantity shouldn’t exceed delivered quantity so no GR leads to a quantity situation that will trigger blocking / restriction

Option 2: Tolerance limits that block invoices when GR quantity = 0

  • In Public Cloud tolerance limits are maintained via Set Tolerance Limits (101947) in CBC

 

  • To control whether the system warns / blocks / errors maintain message behavior in Define Message Types for Area M8 (102091)

More details below:

https://userapps.support.sap.com/sap/support/knowledge/en/3052672

Once GR is posted and you’re ready to pay use the Release Blocked Invoices app

More details below:

https://fioriappslibrary.hana.ondemand.com/sap/fix/externalViewer/#/detail/Apps('MRBR')/S35

IMPORTANT: It can release payment blocks that were set during invoice creation in Create Supplier Invoice / Create Supplier Invoice Advanced

More details below:

https://userapps.support.sap.com/sap/support/knowledge/en/3061453

ALTERNATIVE: If you want no invoice until GR by design then onsider Evaluated Receipt Settlement (ERS) the system settles based on GRs so you don’t process supplier invoices for those vendors

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/0e602d466b99490187fcbb30d1dc897c/796fb6531de6b64ce10000000a174cb4.html

Best Regards,

Dawid

entry.title: Re: Issues Migrating from DEV to QAS Using CTMS with SAP...
entry.content:
Hi koide_yuya,

Sorry for my late reply. 

The error "Error detecting MTA major schema version" typically occurs during the deployment of a Multi-Target Application (MTA) when there is a conflict in the schema version between the MTA deployment descriptor and the extension descriptor.

So it seems there is a mismatch between the schema version of MTA deployment  and the deployment ext. descriptor uploaded in cTMS. The schema version for both must be always the same: Defining MTA Extension Descriptors | SAP Help Portal

Note

The format and available options within the extension descriptor may change with newer versions of the MTA specification. You must always specify the schema version option when defining an extension descriptor to inform the SAP BTP which MTA specification version should be used. Furthermore, the schema version used within the extension descriptor and the deployment descriptor should always be the same.

Could you please compare both files?

For example for _schema-version 3.1, this should look like:

ref: https://help.sap.com/doc/multitarget-application-modelv3/Cloud/en-US/The%20Multitarget%20Application%20M%D0%BEdel.pdf

Hope this helps,

Sven

entry.title: Re: SAP BTP - APIM - Demystified: Designing a Single API Proxy with Dynamic Routing for Multiple Tar
entry.content:
@MateuszPiotrowski ,

I found solution for custom monitoring in this case scenario:

ProxyEndPoint - PreFlow in de end after exception raise add java script and statistics.

Add a java script + StatisticsCollection:

Javascript

function setCustomHeaders(){
var path = context.getVariable("proxy.pathsuffix");
var packageName = "Unknown Package";
var iflowName = "Unknown Iflow";

// Lógica de mapeamento dinâmico
if (path.indexOf("/http/cpi/iflowA") > -1) {
    packageName = "PackageSAPSCNBlog";
    iflowName = "Iflow A";
} 
else if (path.indexOf("/http/cpi/iflowB") > -1) {
    packageName = "PackageSAPSCNBlog";
    iflowName = "Iflow B";
} 
else if (path.indexOf("/http/cpi/iflowC") > -1) {
    packageName = "PackageSAPSCNBlog";
    iflowName = "Iflow C";
}
// Create variables
context.setVariable("custom.package_name", packageName);
context.setVariable("custom.iflow_name", iflowName);
}

Statistics Collection:

<!--Specify Stats collector policy to add custom dimensions and measures -->
 <StatisticsCollector async='false' continueOnError='false' enabled='true' xmlns='http://www.sap.com/apimgmt'>
 <Statistics>

<!-- prepopulated template -->
<!-- Uncomment Statistic which needs to be collected and define reference variable-->
<!-- <Statistic name='custom_MessageCount' ref='' type='integer'>0</Statistic> -->
<Statistic name='custom_SAP_Iflow' ref='custom.iflow_name' type='string'>N/A</Statistic>
<Statistic name='custom_SAP_Package' ref='custom.package_name' type='string'>N/A</Statistic>

</Statistics>
</StatisticsCollector>

 

 

Create Metrics in the Analytic Tab: add the values from StatisticCollector

Create a custom view:

Monitor:

Thanks for the conversation.

Regards,

Viana.

entry.title: Re: Select package size to solve 'Time out' Dump.
entry.content:
So, your issue is about running the program in dialog (there's no timeout in background).

Before thinking to avoid the timeout, do you know how much time it takes? Are you sure that the users will accept to wait so much time?

SELECT with PACKAGE SIZE means that you have to use ENDSELECT so it's like a loop.
COMMIT WORK will close the database "cursor" (see ABAP documentation for explanation) so it would do a short dump inside SELECT ENDSELECT. There's no simple solution to avoid the timeout in dialog if you do a full table scan (no key field).

entry.title: Creating an SAP CAP with test.http application to test ODTA V4 connected to SQLite Database.
entry.content:
Purpose.
To be able to test a CAP Application using ODATA V4 URL that is connected to an SQLite database.
Then create a test.http page to send ODATA V4 calls to perform Get and Post request for testing.
Overview.
First to create an SAP CAP test application that is using ODATA v4.
Then enable the SQLite database and be able to perform CRUD operation.
to test via the ODATA V4 using a test.http page to issue the ODATA calls.

PREREQUISETS.
• Access to SAP Business Application Studio.
• If developing on Premise Visual Studio Code and all the SAP extensions installed.
• Creating a test CAP Application.
• Adding SQLight Database and importing data.
• Creating a test http page to send ODATA GET and Post calls for testing.

Creating a CAP Test application.
1- Login to the SAP Business Application Studio.
2- From the Menu select go to Terminal -> New terminal.

3- Run the following command to create our project
     user: ~ $ cds init bookshop
4- Next, go to File → Open Folder and choose the bookshop.
5- Go to Terminal → New Terminal to open a command line window within VS Code and run the
     following command in the root level of your project: user: bookshop $ npm install

Once this is done, we are now ready to start creating our application.
6- In terminal window run the following command
     user: bookshop cds watch

Doing this will allow us to monitor the server each time we make a change.

We should see something like this
cds serve all --with-mocks --in-memory?

watching: cds,csn,csv,ts,mjs,cjs,js,json,properties,edmx,xml,env,css,gif,html,jpg,png,svg...
live reload enabled for browsers
_______________________


No models found in db/,srv/,app/,schema,services.
Waiting for some to arrive...

If we note the data is in --with-mocks --in-memory. this is telling us if we make any changes 
such as a POST the data will only be in Memory once the server is stopped the data will 
be lost. 

7- Next, we will need to add some files to our Project.

8- Go to the srv folder and right click and create a file called cat-service.cds

9- Add the following code to the cat-service.cds.

using bookshop as my from '../db/schema';

service CatalogService {

  entity Books @Capabilities.SelectSupport as projection on my.Books;

  entity Authors @Capabilities.SelectSupport as projection on my.Authors;

  entity Orders @Capabilities.SelectSupport as projection on my.Orders;

}

This will allow us to update the tables.

10- Next Right click on the /srv folder and create file called
       cat-service.js

11- Past the following content into cat-service.js

module.exports = (srv) => {

 

 // Reply mock data for Books...

 srv.on ('READ', 'Books', ()=>[

   { ID:201, title:'Wuthering Heights', author_ID:101, stock:12 },

   { ID:251, title:'The Raven', author_ID:150, stock:333 },

   { ID:252, title:'Eleonora', author_ID:150, stock:555 },

   { ID:271, title:'Catweazle', author_ID:170, stock:222 },

 ])

 

 // Reply mock data for Authors...

 srv.on ('READ', 'Authors', ()=>[

   { ID:101, name:'Emily Brontë' },

   { ID:150, name:'Edgar Allen Poe' },

   { ID:170, name:'Richard Carpenter' },

 ])

}


Next, we need to add our data model and adapt service definition

12- Right click on the db folder and create file called schema.cds

13- Past the follow code into the file schema.cds.

namespace my.bookshop;

using { Country, managed } from '@sap/cds/common';

entity Books {

  key ID : Integer;

  title  : localized String;

  author : Association to Authors;

  stock  : Integer;

}

entity Authors {

  key ID : Integer;

  name   : String;

  books  : Association to many Books on books.author = $self;

}

entity Orders : managed {

  key ID  : UUID;

  book    : Association to Books;

  country : Country;

  amount  : Integer;

}


After adding the files make sure you save if you do not have the auto save on

14- Next Open another Terminal window and run the following command.

15- user: bookshop $ cds add data

This command will add csv files data under the db/data folder.

16- Open the file db/data/bookshop-Authors.csv
17- Add the following

           101,Emily Brontë 
           107,Charlote Brontë
           150,Edgar Allen Poe 
           170,Richard Carpenter

NOTE: Do not delete the Colum's ID,name

18- Next go to file db/data/bookshop-Books.csv and add the following data.

201,Wuthering Heights,101,12
207,Jane Eyre,107,11
251,The Raven,150,333
252,Eleonora,150,555
271,Catweazle,170,22

NOTE: Do not delete the Colum's  ID,title,author_ID,stock

19- If the cds watch is still up and running, we will need to shut it down
       do a Ctrl c in the terminal windows to shut down.

20- We will need to configure the package.json this tells the start up to use the SQLite database.
21- Add the following code snippet 

},

  "cds": { "requires": {

   "db": {

      "kind": "sqlite",

      "credentials": { "url": "db/bookshop.sqlite" },

      "private": true}

   }

The package.json should look like this after editing.

{

  "name": "bookshop",

  "version": "1.0.0",

  "description": "A simple CAP project.",

  "dependencies": {

    "@sap/cds": "^9",

    "express": "^4"

  },

  "devDependencies": {

    "@cap-js/sqlite": "^2"

  },

  "scripts": {

    "start": "cds-serve"

 },

  "cds": { "requires": {

   "db": {

      "kind": "sqlite",

      "credentials": { "url": "db/bookshop.sqlite" },

      "private": true}

   }

}}

 

22- Next will need to deploy our SQLite database Open a termina windows and run
        the following command

23- user: bookshop $ cds deploy

24- Next in the terminal window run the following command.
25- User: bookshop $ sqlite3 db/bookshop.sqlite -cmd .dump

If we go to the folder /db  folder we will see bookshop.sqlite database fille was created.

26- Go to the terminal window and stop SQLite and go back to your project directory,
27- Choose Ctrl + C.
28-In the same terminal window run cds watch to start the server.

We are looking to see if in fact the Server and the SQLite are working.
here are the startup messages.

[cds] - connect using bindings from: { registry: '~/.cds-services.json' }

[cds] - connect to db > sqlite { url: 'db/bookshop.sqlite' }

[cds] - using auth strategy {

  kind: 'mocked',

  impl: 'node_modules/@sap/cds/lib/srv/middlewares/auth/basic-auth.js'

}

[cds] - serving AdminService {

  at: [ '/odata/v4/admin' ],

  decl: 'srv/admin-service.cds:2',

  impl: 'node_modules/@sap/cds/srv/app-service.js'

}

[cds] - serving CatalogService {

  at: [ '/odata/v4/catalog' ],

  decl: 'srv/cat-service.cds:3',

  impl: 'srv/cat-service.js'

}

[cds] - server listening on { url: 'http://localhost:4004' }

[cds] - server v9.5.2 launched in 324 ms

[cds] - [ terminate with ^C ]

Now that we have our CAP application and it is using the SQLite database
we can now create a test web page to send ODATA calls to our web server and the data will
be fetched from the SQLite database we also can post data, and it will be saved to the database.

 How to create a test http web page.

23- In the root of your project, create a file called test.http file
24- Copy and paste the following into the test.http file.

###

#

# Browse Books

#

GET http://localhost:4004/odata/v4/catalog/Books?

  # &$select=title,stock

  # &$expand=currency

  # &sap-language=de

 

###

#

# Get Author with ID 101

#

GET http://localhost:4004/odata/v4/catalog/Authors(115)

 

###

# Note the content type

# Update Author with ID

# We can post and add authors

POST http://localhost:4004/odata/v4/catalog/Authors

Content-Type: application/json

 

{"ID": 115, "name": "Mary May"}

 

###

# Note the Content-Type

# Order a Book

#

POST http://localhost:4004/odata/v4/catalog/Orders

Content-Type: application/json;IEEE754Compatible=true

 

{"book_ID": 201, "amount": 5}

###

#

# Get the Database catalog

#

 

GET http://localhost:4004/odata/v4/catalog/

  # Get the catalog from the database

###

#

# Default html page

#

GET http://localhost:4004/

  # to Get the html page


This file can be used with the REST client to make requests against your service.
The generic handlers CAP provides sent the responses to web server http://localhost:4004.

We are not limited to what is in the test.http we can add additional requests to see the effect and the responses.

Next if the Server is not up and running go to a terminal window and start the server.
25- cds watch.

26- Next, go to the test.http file and open it.
27- Go to Update Author with ID.
28- Change the ID number "201" and change the name to "johnny Top".

29- In the Test.http file click on the send request to send the changes. 
  

As we can see on the Right-hand side the responses, we can see that the table was updated.
we can also send request to do simply GET response to verify.  

If we need to add additional tests, we can simply do the following.

30- Open the test.http file.

31- Copy and paste the following code.

Send response

###

#

# Default html page

#

GET http://localhost:4004/

  # to Get the html page

Note: That it will automatically add the send response there is no need to add it. 

32- Once updated simple click on send response.

After click send Request the above is what should happen, we can see a successful request. 

To add additional ODATA V4 tests can be done depending on your needs.

For example, if we needed or wanted to update Books for example we could add a URL to our test.http
Example:

33- Go to the schema.cds file in our project.
34- Look at the table definition for books.

namespace bookshop;

using { Country, managed } from '@sap/cds/common';

entity Books {

  key ID : Integer;

  title  : localized String;

  author : Association to Authors;

  stock  : Integer;

}

entity Authors {

  key ID : Integer;

  name   : String;

  books  : Association to many Books on books.author = $self;

}

 

entity Orders : managed {

  key ID  : UUID;

  book    : Association to Books;

  country : Country;

  amount  : Integer;}

Creating our URI
{"ID": datavalue, "title": "datavalue", "author_ID": "datavalue", "stock": "datavalue"}


In breaking this down we can see we have the Row name in blue there are denoted with double quotes “ “  and separated by colin  :

Then in double quotes we add our data within the is in a double quote format is very important
when added data it formats of the columns need to be consider.   
Note the ID is the only data field that is not in double quoted.

Note: Format and understanding the data types of the ROWS are critical
we can’t send sting of data to integer, so it is important to understand the Rows and the data types. Alway check each column and data types are being used in the database. 
 
35- We can craft a Post request with the information we have.
36- Add the following to the Test.http file and send Request 

###

#

# Post Books

#

POST http://localhost:4004/odata/v4/catalog/Books

Content-Type: application/json

{"ID": 601, "title": "Mydays", "author_ID": "5", "stock": "20"}

When we send the request, on executing the following result set are returned.

HTTP/1.1 201 Created X-Powered-By: Express X-Correlation-ID: 71a2326a-4aee-4b1c-937e-c2198316714e

OData-Version: 4.0

location: Books(601)

Content-Type: application/json; charset=utf-8

Content-Length: 95

Date: Wed, 10 Dec 2025 20:06:27 GMT

Connection: close

 "@odata.context": "$metadata#Books/$entity", "ID": 601, "title": "Mydays", "author_ID": 5, "stock": 20 }

The key factor is understanding the table definition and the data that is expected.
Here we can see we were successful in updating Books

We can create a simple cap application then add a database to store our data. To further enhance our testing, we added a test.http page and added ODATA V4 URI to the page to test Get and Post request.  
We further enhanced the page to update books as well as update authors. This makes a great test suite when testing data and the ODATA to see what the result sets will be before deploying the application to the cloud. Why all of this is important is the ODATA V4 GET and POST calls are 
successful in the test application that are going or should be successful when deploying.
Also, as a developer helps simplify creating a test page.

entry.title: Re: API Handling Unit SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition
entry.content:
Dear @Charisma_fitra,

That message isn’t specific to the HandlingUnit API, it’s the classic EWM/LE integration guardrail

Wait until updates of dependent data are completed, often message class typically means the delivery is still being updated in an asynchronous queue or the queue is stuck. While that update is running the system blocks another posting for the same related object often the same inbound delivery / same delivery item context so your 2nd HU call hits the lock/serialization check

SAP own guidance for the same error in Public Cloud is check the delivery’s queue in Warehouse Monitor->Tools-> Message Queue because the error often indicates a stuck queue and the real root cause is shown inside that queue entry

SAP Note below:

https://me.sap.com/notes/0003300867

What to do:

1. Your integration is posting faster than the backend can finish dependent updates
Even if the first API call returns success, follow-on updates delivery status, HU status, stock figures, WM document links can still be processing

So:

  • Do not call selfPostGoodsReceipt in parallel for HUs belonging to the same inbound delivery
  • If you get this error wait and retry

2. Or the queue is stuck then waiting will never help so find and resolve the stuck queue

  • Open Warehouse Monitor
  • Go to Tools->Message Queue
  • Filter/search by the inbound delivery
  • If you see a stuck entry open it to see the real error text and then reprocess after fixing the cause like in SAP Note above

Summary, if:

  • you implement retry with backoff
  • no stuck queue exists for that delivery
  • and it still reliably fails on 2nd HU

then raising an SAP incident

Best Regards,

Dawid

entry.title: Re: Performance Review Delegation : permissions
entry.content:
Hello! 

Thank you for raising this documentation gap to us! 

We now have corrected the KBA 3525071 - Delegation for Performance Reviews Feature Overview - SAP for Me to be more clear:

  • Administrator Permissions > Manage Delegation > Delegation Management: Grants access to the Delegation Management admin center tool. The target population for this permission will determine who can be selected as a delegator and a delegatee. Additionally, the permissions granted to the selected delegator will determine which forms templates can be delegated and who can be selected as a delegatee by an Admin.  

The Manage delegation tool is usually granted to Admins only, so the target population should be both delegators and delegatees; additionally this would be restricted by the delegator-delegatee permission, meaning that the admin could not delegate to someone outside the delegator target population.

regards, Jenia

SAP Support

entry.title: Actual Costing settlement completed with CKMLMV-039 / CKMLMV-042 warnings after upgrade
entry.content:
After upgrading our SAP S/4HANA system, we started receiving the following warnings during the Costing Cockpit / Settlement step:

  • CKMLMV-039 – Iteration of cycle diverges in currency/valuation

  • CKMLMV-042 – Cycle recalculated after removing critical edges

Key points:

  • Settlement completes successfully

  • No errors 

  • FI postings are balanced

  • Actual prices and cost component split look correct in CKM3N

System setup:

  • Single company code

  • Multiple plants 

Before the upgrade, the same setup did not produce these warnings.

Is this expected behavior after the upgrade, and can these warnings be considered informational only if settlement completes without errors? What causes it and how can i do removed it?

entry.title: SAP Continuous Influence Session for SAP S/4HANA Utilities: Status Update January 2026
entry.content:
The year 2026 has begun, and it is time again for an update on our SAP Continuous Influence Session for SAP S/4HANA Utilities. We had started this session in July 2023 as our single channel for collecting your suggestions for improvements related to SAP S/4HANA Utilities:

For more details, read my previous blog post New SAP Continuous Influence session for SAP S/4HANA Utilities.

As of 7 January 2026, we have received a total of 129 improvement requests (IR) in our session:

39 IRs have already been delivered since the session started. Here is a list of the 23 IRs delivered during the last twelve months, starting with those that have received most votes:

  • IR 339315 - Weitere Suchfelder in der Verbrauchsstellenübersicht (Customer Engagement/ IC Agent) wer... 
  • IR 323239 - Public API for Developer Extensibility: RAP Interface for Utilities Installation / Anlage 
  • IR 323240 - Public API for Developer Extensibility: RAP Interface for Utilties Metering Point / Zählpunkt 
  • IR 357107 - Re-plausibilisation for later meter readings (ISU_DM_MR_FUTURE_PLAUSI active) 
  • IR 323245 - Public API for Developer Extensibility: RAP Interface for Utilties Device/Gerät incl. Gerätebewegung 
  • IR 355596 - RTP-Schnittstelle mit Eingabevariable in Komponente / RTP-Interface with Input variable in component 
  • IR 323241 - Public API for Developer Extensibility: RAP Interface for Utilties Premise / Verbrauchsstelle 
  • IR 323242 - Public API for Developer Extensibility: RAP Interface for Utilties Connection Object/Anschlussobjekt 
  • IR 323244 - Public API for Developer Extensibility: RAP Interface for Utilties Device Location/Geräteplatz 
  • IR 354703 - Additional search options are needed in the free-text search of premise(Customer Engagement/IC Agent)

You can also view the current list of all improvement requests delivered within the SAP Continuous Influence sesison for SAP S/4HANA Utilities under https://influence.sap.com/sap/ino/#/campaign/3504/ideas-completed.

3 IRs have been accepted for development and are planned to be delivered in Q1-Q2/2026:

  • IR 348044 - Profile Status and Status of Billing Orders do not correspond

5 IRs have the status "Planned (Long-Term)", which means they have been identified as being a larger investment and have been incorporated into the product roadmap for SAP S/4HANA Utilities:

  • IR 330477 - Flexible Aggregation von Lastgängen / Flexible aggregation of load profiles

7 IRs are currently under review, 2 IRs have status "Need More Info", and 3 IRs have the status "For Long-term Consideration". 

14 IRs have the status „Acknowledged”, 5 of them have 7 or more votes and are close to being reviewed (10 votes required to do so).

54 IRs have the status “Not planned”, and we had to reject most of them either because they did not receive enough votes within twelve months or because they are out of scope for the session SAP S/4HANA Utilities. We would like to remind you that within this session dedicated to the utilities industry, we can only acknowledge and accept such IRs that are related to the utilities-industry specific part of SAP S/4HANA. For further options for influencing SAP products (beyond SAP S/4HANA Utilities) please see How Customers and Partners Can Give Input to the Roadmap of the SAP S/4HANA Cloud, Private Edition. A comprehensive list of all active SAP Customer Influence sessions is available here: SAP Continuous Influence Sessions - Overview.

A big thank you to all improvement request owners and other contributors for their active participation in our SAP Continuous Influence Session so far! Please continue to do so – by submitting your own ideas or by voting for improvement requests already submitted by your peers. Remember that such improvement requests that have not reached the required threshold of 10 votes within 12 months will be rejected automatically. Please be encouraged to validate and prioritize the important ones from your point of view.

Please note that a valid S user is required to participate in our (and other) SAP Continuous Influence session(s). For details see knowledge base article 3014377 - Accessing the Continuous Influence Session "SAP S/4HANA Utilities".

We appreciate your input that helps us to continuously improve SAP S/4HANA Utilities according to your business requirements.

This is snapshot for my DB table with 2 fields , one for created date and another for created timestamp

@EndUserText.label : 'Sales Order Header table - Test'
@AbapCatalog.enhancement.category : #EXTENSIBLE_CHARACTER_NUMERIC
@AbapCatalog.tableCategory : #TRANSPARENT
@AbapCatalog.deliveryClass : #A
@AbapCatalog.dataMaintenance : #RESTRICTED
define table zsales_header {

  key mandt      : mandt not null;
  key vbeln      : vbeln_va not null;
  erdat          : abp_creation_date;
  created_tmstmp : abp_creation_tstmpl;
  kunnr          : kunnr;

This is from my ROOT view

@AccessControl.authorizationCheck: #NOT_REQUIRED
@EndUserText.label: 'Root View Entity for Sales Header'
@Metadata.ignorePropagatedAnnotations: true
define root view entity ZR_Sales_Header as select from YI_SALESORD_HDR_TEST
composition[1..*] of YI_SALES_ITEM as  _SalesOrdItem
association[0..1] to I_OverallSDProcessStatusText as _OverallProcStatusText
  on  $projection.GBSTK = _OverallProcStatusText.OverallSDProcessStatus 
  and _OverallProcStatusText.Language = $session.system_language
association[1..1] to ZI_CustomerNameText as _CustomerName
  on $projection.KUNNR = _CustomerName.Customer  
{
    key VBELN,
    @Semantics.systemDate.createdAt: true
    ERDAT,
    @Semantics.systemDateTime.createdAt: true
    CreatedTimestamp,
    AUART,
    KUNNR,

 This is snapshot of behaviour definition where both the fields are marked as read only

managed implementation in class zbp_r_sales_header unique;
strict ( 2 );

define behavior for ZR_Sales_Header alias ZS_Header
persistent table zsales_header
lock master
authorization master ( instance )
early numbering
//etag master <field_name>
{
  create;
  update;
  delete;
  association _SalesOrdItem { create; }

  field ( readonly ) VBELN, ERDAT, CreatedTimestamp;

  //Dynamic Feature Control
  field( features : instance ) gbstk;

So the fields are displayed as read only but they are saved with blank values (both timestamp and ERDAT) when creating a new record. (If user enters some values for these date and timestamp fields manually then it gets saved successfully)

The other fields work fine for Create operation.

entry.title: SAP Cloud Integration/CPI: How to Return Custom Error Messages to Sender - available options
entry.content:
Dear Community,

I often receive questions about how to return meaningful error responses to senders in synchronous interfaces.

Although there are some posts on this topic, there's no definitive tutorial explaining what's possible and what isn't.

For some of you, this will be an aha moment; for others, some aspects may be familiar. However, even experienced experts should find this a useful synthesized summary.

This is a brief showcase of the options we have as integration architects and developers.

 

Problem with ERROR END EVENT

The main point is that it doesn't matter whether an iFlow finishes with an ERROR END EVENT or ESCALATION END EVENT (both unsuccessful end steps). In such cases, the HTTP status of the message will be 500, and a generic error message will be returned to the sender. The standard status in the CI monitor will be set to FAILED/ESCALATED.

You can try to set your own message body and expect to see it but... this will not happen (although it is quite intuitive approach, right?)

Message returned to Sender:

Optionally, you can return error details (the full exception visible also in the CI monitor) to the sender by checking "Return Exception to Sender" but we're still in not expected situation: a standard error message that's often unclear and doesn't provide enough information to resolve the root cause of the problem.

Remark: Additionally, sometimes returning the raw exception isn't recommended from a security perspective, as we don't want to expose internal logic to the external world.

Bottom line: By finishing an iFlow with an ERROR END/ESCALATION END step, you cannot set a custom error response message and/or custom HTTP status code using Content Modifier and/or a Groovy script. It will always be 500 with a standard error message.

So the main question is: how do we accomplish our goal?

 

Resolution (although still partial) = End Message step

Finish your iFlow with an END MESSAGE event (in the exception subprocess). Only if you finish with a "successful" end step can you set a custom error response and/or custom HTTP status code.

See the simple iFlow example below.

Remark: this iflow does not have sense as there is no logic inside - created only for purpose of this exercise.

In step: "Check if Basic Auth" - I am checking Authorization header, whether contains prefix "Basic". If yes - it means that Sender try to authenticate via Basic authentication and not expected OAuth client credentials. I do not want to allow this to happen although possible if no circumvent solution applied.

Btw. better idea is to secure iflow by APIM if used already (other features are required like throttling or IP whitelisting). But this is topic for different blog 🙂

In Exception Subprocess, I'm using a standard Content Modifier step to return what I need to the sender, but you can also do this in a Groovy script.

Standard Header: CamelHttpResponseCode = 401

Outcome: iFlow finished with status COMPLETED with custom information returned to sender.

 

OK... we've delivered what we wanted: our sender is probably happier now, but the operations team in CI monitoring/CALM won't know that this message actually ended with an error and wasn't truly successful, although the status being set to COMPLETED.

 

Resolution = End Message step + custom status

What we still need is to somehow mark such messages.

A few options:

  • Set a custom header in groovy script, e.g. MessageStatus=BasicAuthFailed
  • Set a custom status (recommended) by utilizing the standard property SAP_MessageProcessingLogCustomStatus

Outcome: iFlow finished with main status COMPLETED ... but also with our custom status

The ability to filter makes this truly practical:

 

Now, most of you are thinking: OK, this is good enough, but you still need to remember to filter by custom status, and a message visible as COMPLETED isn't really completed, but failed.

Can we leave our iFlow with status FAILED?

Short answer: No.

SAP is not supporting this: https://me.sap.com/notes/0003316452

Quote: "This is not currently possible in SAP CI. SAP has introduced SAP Influence to allow customers to provide feedback and requirements."

I haven't found an influence idea for this yet as well, so this will not happen in near future.

Is this over? Are all options explained?

 

Intermediary solution

Actually, there's one more option that can be helpful if leaving the iFlow with status FAILED is equally important as setting a custom error response.

As is often the case, if standard features don't deliver what you want, you can rely on scripting 🙂

It's enough to add this single line to your Groovy script to set a response message for your sender:

throw new Exception("Basic Authentication now allowed")

And set this setting (important)

This is what's visible to the sender:

and in CI monitor:

Outcome: iFlow with status FAILED, custom response (although somewhat messy), HTTP status code returned... still 500.

Yes, as in real life, you often can't have everything 😞

Remark: if you use already API management, it can be good idea to utilize it: refine final response message and set proper HTTP response status code in API policy.

 

CONCLUSION

Options to return a custom response:

  1. Leave iFlow with END MESSAGE and:
    • Set response message in body
    • Set standard header CamelHttpResponseCode
    • Set custom status in standard property: SAP_MessageProcessingLogCustomStatus

    DRAWBACK: iFlow has still main status COMPLETED

  2. Throw exception in Groovy script: throw new Exception("error message here")

    DRAWBACK: HTTP status code returned to sender = 500 & response isn't clean (our text + framework text)

 

Please share any comments, improvements or alternative approaches - I'm always eager to learn!

Best regards,
Mateusz

entry.title: Automating Amazon SP-API Data Extraction in BTP Integration Suite
entry.content:
Part 1: The Problem Statement

When integrating with the Amazon Selling Partner API (SP-API), developers often run into a significant roadblock: Data Volume vs API Limits.

Imagine you need to sync thousands of financial transactions for a month-end reconciliation. Amazon doesn’t provide this data in one massive payload; instead, it serves data in "pages". If your integration only makes a single call, you are likely leaving 90% of your data behind.

Furthermore, the SP-API requires a complex dance of OAuth2 token exchange and header-based authentication. The "problem" is two-fold:

Authentication: How do we dynamically retrieve and inject the “x-amz-access-token” into every call?

Completeness: How do we design a "smart" loop in Integration Suite that recognizes when a "NextToken" exists and continues fetching data until the very last record is secured?

Part 2: Deep Dive

In the Integration Suite, XPaths are the "surgical tools" used to extract specific data from an XML payload.

  1. Authentication and Token Management

The integration begins by preparing the credentials required to request an access token from Amazon's identity service.

Initial Configuration (set_getToken_Properties): The flow sets the necessary OAuth2 parameters in the message body, including grant_type, refresh_token, client_id, and client_secret.

Token Request (get_Token): An HTTP POST call is made to: https://api.amazon.com/auth/o2/token.

  1. Extracting the Access Token

After the get_Token call, the JSON response is converted to XML. To use this token in subsequent calls, we use a Content Modifier.

XPath: /root/access_token (Source Type: XPath and Data Type: java.lang.String)

Purpose: This extracts the bearer token string. By storing this in a Message Header (specifically named x-amz-access-token), IS automatically includes it in the HTTP headers of the next request to Amazon.

  1. Initial Data Fetch (The "First Page")

Before entering a loop, the system attempts to fetch the first batch of financial events.

Request Header Configuration: The x-amz-access-token is passed into the allowed headers so it can be sent in the outbound request.

First API Call (get_FI_Events): An HTTP GET request is sent to the Financial Events endpoint. The URL includes parameters like PostedAfter and PostedBefore to define the date range for the data sync.

  1. Capturing the Pagination Link (NextToken)

This is the most critical step for the loop. When you call the Financial Events API, the response contains a field that tells you if more data is available.

XPath: /FIevents/payload/NextToken (Source Type: XPath and Data Type: java.lang.String)

Step: set_NextToken (Content Modifier)

Behavior: * If a next page exists, this XPath retrieves a long alphanumeric string.

If no more pages exist, the field is empty (null).

  1. Implementing the Pagination Loop

The “Router” and “Looping Process Call” steps do not use an XPath directly, but rather an Exchange Property derived from the XPath above.

Expression Type: Non-XML

Condition: ${property.P_NextToken} != ''

Logic: As long as the P_NextToken property is not empty, the Router will direct the message back into the get FI Events in local process loop. Inside that process, the HTTP query is dynamically updated:

Query: ...&NextToken=${property.P_NextToken}

Part 3: Summary Table

Step

Component

XPath / Expression

Target Storage

Auth

Content Modifier

/root/access_token

Header: x-amz-access-token

Pagination

Content Modifier

/FIevents/payload/NextToken

Property: P_NextToken

Routing

Router

${property.P_NextToken} != ''

Route to "Loop_Route"

Iteration

HTTP Request

...&NextToken=${property.P_NextToken}

Outbound Query Parameter

Part 4: Error Handling & Resilience

In a looping integration, a single failure can either stall your process or create an infinite loop. To make this production-ready, consider these layers of defense:

The "Circuit Breaker" (Max Iterations): As seen in the configuration, setting the Max. Numbers of Iterations (e.g., 200) is your insurance policy. If the API somehow enters a state where it returns the same NextToken repeatedly, this setting prevents your IS tenant from crashing or hitting memory limits.

The "Pause" Script: In the looping sub-process, there is a Pause Script step. This is a best practice to avoid API Throttling. Amazon SP-API has strict "leaky bucket" quotas. Adding a small Groovy script (e.g., Thread.sleep(1000)) helps stay within the allowed request rate.

Exception Sub-Processes: If the get_FI_Events call fails (401 Unauthorized or 500 Internal Server Error), the loop should be caught by an Exception Sub-Process.

Part 5: Conclusion & Best Practices

Automating the extraction of Amazon Financial Events within SAP BTP Integration Suite is more than just a "mapping" exercise; it is an exercise in state management. By using a combination of XPaths to capture session state (tokens) and Loop Routers to manage flow state, you create a robust, hands-off synchronization engine.

Header Cleaning: After the get_Token step, ensure you are only passing the necessary headers to Amazon. Use the "Allowed Headers" field in the HTTP adapter to prevent internal SAP headers from being sent to the external API.

Externalize Parameters: Values like the client_id, refresh_token, and even the MaxResultsPerPage should be Externalized. This allows your operations team to update credentials or tuning parameters without redeploying the entire integration package.

Traceability: Use the "Custom Header" logging feature in IS to log the P_NextToken value. If a specific page of data is missing or corrupted, you can track exactly which API call handled that data.

entry.title: Accessing SAP BTP Core Services APIs Using SAP Cloud Management Service (CIS)
entry.content:
Accessing SAP Cloud Integration (SAP CI) information programmatically has become quite common today.
Whether it’s iFlows, message processing logs, or deployed artifacts, SAP CI OData APIs make this information easily available, all we need is SAP CI technical user with the right roles.

This convenience often raises a natural question:

Can we do the same for SAP BTP as well?

Can we programmatically access:

  • SAP BTP account details ?
  • Subaccounts and entitlements ?
  • Services and runtime information ?

The answer is Yes, but unlike SAP CI, the authentication and access model for SAP BTP Core Services is fundamentally different.

 

Why SAP BTP Is Different from SAP CI?

When accessing SAP CI OData APIs, authentication is straightforward:

  • Use an SAP CI technical user
  • Assign the required roles
  • Call the OData endpoint

However, SAP BTP Core Services APIs (Accounts, Entitlements, Directories, etc.) do not work this way.

One cannot:

  • Use SAP CI technical users
  • Use basic authentication
  • Directly call these APIs without a management service
SAP BTP protects these APIs using OAuth 2.0 and requires a dedicated management service to act as a trusted client.
And this is exactly where the SAP Cloud Management Service (CIS) comes into play.
 

Introducing SAP Cloud Management Service (CIS)

To access SAP BTP Core Services APIs, SAP mandates the use of: SAP Cloud Management Service – CIS plan

CIS acts as:

  • An authorized OAuth client
  • A secure gateway to SAP BTP management APIs
  • The mechanism through which access tokens are issued for Core Services

Once CIS is configured, SAP Cloud Integration can securely access SAP BTP Core Services APIs.

 

Create SAP Cloud Management Service Instance

Step 1: BTP Cockpit --> Subaccount --> Service Marketplace --> Search “CIS”

Step 2: Create an instance of CIS using the three dots present on the top right of the tile.

Pick “central-viewer” as the plan and click on create

You can check the scope of each plan here : SAP Cloud Management Service - Service Plans | SAP Help Portal
Once this step is done, CIS will be available in the Instances column of the subaccount.

Step 3: Now create a Service key for this instance.

As soon as service key is created ServiceKey cis.json file is ready for the download.

The JSON looks like this :

Among the endpoints in the above picture, our focus is on the endpoint, which will give us the details related to SAP BTP Account.

"accounts_service_url": "https://accounts-service.cfapps.eu10.hana.ondemand.com"

Now to access this URL, we need to setup OAuth 2.0 Credentials on SAP CI using the details provided in this JSON file.

 

Setting up OAuth 2.0 Credentials on SAP CI

Refer the JSON file and configure the security artifact as shown below.

Token Service URL : <<uaa_url>>/oauth/token
Client ID : << clientid >>
Client Secret : << clientsecret >>
Custom Parameters : grantType : clientCredentials
 

SAP CI Iflow:

We have all the configuration in place, now the most interesting part, lets deploy and test the flow.

HTTP Adapter Configurations:

Base URL: https://accounts-service.cfapps.eu10.hana.ondemand.com (can be found in the JSON file)
Resource to fetch information of Global Account: /accounts/v1/globalAccount 

Address: https://accounts-service.cfapps.eu10.hana.ondemand.com/accounts/v1/globalAccount

Other resources of this API can be found here https://api.sap.com/package/SAPCloudPlatformCoreServices/rest

Credentails Name: As created above

 

Demo:

Lets deploy and execute the flow now:

 

 

Response: The information of the SAP BTP Global Account is seen in the response.

 

Conclusion:

SAP BTP Core Services APIs follow a different and more secure access model. These APIs are protected using OAuth 2.0 and require the SAP Cloud Management Service (CIS) as the authorized gateway.

Once CIS is configured, consuming SAP BTP Core Services APIs from SAP Cloud Integration becomes seamless, enabling automation, governance, and platform-level insights. Understanding this distinction is essential for designing robust and future-ready integration scenarios on SAP BTP.

Hope this helps!

Cheers,

Punith

entry.title: Custom fields for enterprise search (SAP Cloud ERP)
entry.content:
Hello SAP Community,

we are currently working on extending Enterprise Search in order to make our custom fields searchable across different business scenarios.

In several cases, this worked as expected. For some business objects, we were able to enable the relevant ESH_* CDS views directly within the custom field.

This then allowed us to add these fields to the corresponding search model in Manage Enterprise Search.

As a result, multiple custom fields could be successfully used in Enterprise Search.

However, we have encountered a limitation for other business scenarios. For objects such as Purchase Orders and Outbound Deliveries, no ESH_* CDS views are available. Additionally, in the Manage Enterprise Search app, the option to add custom fields to the search model is not offered for these business objects.

As a consequence, several of our custom fields cannot be made available via Enterprise Search, even though the business requirement is comparable to scenarios where this functionality is supported. This leads to an inconsistent user experience and makes it more difficult for users to efficiently find related transactions across documents.

This raises the following questions:

  • Why is Enterprise Search not supported consistently across all business scenarios in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition?

  • Is there any supported workaround to make custom fields for Purchase Orders (or Outbound Deliveries) searchable via Enterprise Search?

  • Is Enterprise Search support for custom fields in Purchase Orders and Outbound Deliveries planned or currently discussed on the SAP roadmap?

Thank you very much in advance for your insights and experiences.

Best regards,
Marlene

entry.title: Re: Custom Situation Handling Trigger Accumulation Issue...
entry.content:
Hi @zajde1jc ,

I realize your post has been sitting here unanswered for quite a while, so I'm not sure if this is still relevant for you. If it is, then what you could do is activate the event trace (note with instructions) to validate that the events are sent at correctly in the system. If they are, the next thing you can check is if the events are correctly linked to Situation Handling via SWE2 (you should see entries for the receiver type SIT_V_2.0 for CL_SD_BIL_BD_EVENT-CREATED and -CHANGED). If the linkages are not there, you can try to disable and then re-enable your situation type (assuming you are in a dev/quality system). And if this does not resolve your issue, it would be good if you create a support ticket, so someone from our team can have look at your system.

Best regards,
Sebastian

entry.title: Re: 1H 2026 Onboarding and Onboarding 1.0 Compliance Updates
entry.content:
@AngithaBiju1 , @jeanmarc_regnus , @mhark957  and @fosterr8 :

Compliance Forms (for all supported countries, including USA and Canada) are updated as their governments issue to us the new versions, which we must take time to review & transcripe, code & implement, then patch & upload to Production.

Our usual process is to upload these New Forms to Production during Q1 of any given year; on average, Onboarding (current version) takes less time for us to complete as it doesn't require a code patch.

The Federal W-4, as well as the Federal T-D1 and Provincial TD-1s, are now available in Production for Onboarding customers. These were added in on 5 January 2026.

The Federal W-4, as well as the Federal T-D1 and Provincial TD-1s, will be avaiable on 15 January for Onboarding 1.0. customers.

Other additional forms will be patched and made available soon, and I will update their patch dates here, as well as in our official documentation.

entry.title: Multi‑Payee Scenario – REA2 Condition Type Not Determined
entry.content:
Hello Experts,

In the multi‑payee scenario, when the Sold‑to and Bill‑to are different, the system is not determining the REA2 condition type. However, at the contract level under Condition Usage, it does not show any open accruals — all accruals appear as reversed.
Additionally, at the accounting document level, the accrual reversal is also not reflected.

Request you to please share your inputs.

entry.title: Part 1 - Understanding ‘Define Identifiers To Search In Message Processing Logs’
entry.content:
SAP integration Suite provides a wonderful tab in your integration flow titled 'Design Guidelines'. These guidelines ensure that your iFlow conforms to standards and peak efficiency (and consistency). When you run the design guidelines and if a section becomes 'Non-Compliant', many of the areas will provide a nice tooltip explaining the reason for the issue. However, some of them are too vague and leaves my developers wondering what to do next. These article series will identify a few that needed a little more in-depth explanation to help make it Compliant.

Throughout the series we'll discuss many of the available options in the design guidelines but today the focus is on 'Define Identifiers To Search In Message Processing Logs'. To meet this requirement, you will need to add four key headers in a content modifier as early as possible in your integration flow (more details to come).

To satisfy this requirement, the following four headers are needed to be added to your integration flow:

  • SAP_Sender  - This identifies the “start” of your integration
  • SAP_Receiver - This identifies the “end” of your integration. Say you are sending from Company A to Company B, in this context Company B is the final receiver
  • SAP_MessageType - The identifier of the type of message this is. Examples include: Create Purchase Order, Delete Sales Order etc.
  • SAP_ApplicationID - This is the unique ID of your flow. For example: a purchase order number, sales order etc.

Understanding the Implementation

Ok so you added this new header to your integration. You are probably thinking “I have 15+ iFlows in this single process, *sigh* I am going to have to add to add to all of them”. If you were thinking that then let me be the first to say “false!” I bet that made you slightly happy? So then how does it work?

Let's look at the above example. In this organization, this company has a Sales Order Creation that has an asynchronous process in the middle. The headers we added in the last section, what iFlow do you think they need to be added in? iFlow A? Why? If you said iFlow A and C, you would be correct (you technically would be also correct with A, B and C). Lets understand why.

Recall that when I mentioned to implement these headers I mentioned that it should be as early as possible? By setting the headers as the first thing in your iFlow A it trickles down to iFlow B! Pretty cool, right!? Unfortunately, since we have an async call to an OData service, iFlow A and B are part of one correlation. This means when it starts back in iFlow C, you need to reset the headers.

Now if you are the type of person who did set these headers in iFlow A and C, do you think the Design Guidelines will be satisfied in iFlow B? If you said no, you sadly would be correct. The design guidelines does allow the developer to “Skip Status” and asks you provide a reason. If you are confident beyond a double that iFlow B will only ever be called by iFlow A then we can be assured that the headers will carry on. If not, you should set the headers in iFlow B to be safe.

If you found this article helpful, please like and comment. Thanks for reading!

entry.title: Utilities Customer Self-Service Agent: Reduce Operational Costs and Enhance Customer Experience
entry.content:
SAP has announced a new Utilities Customer Self-Service Agent for its SAP S/4HANA Utilities solution that enables utility companies to provide human-like customer interactions while significantly reducing operational costs. The AI-powered agent integrates out-of-the-box with SAP S/4HANA Utilities to deliver tailored customer experiences with full understanding of customer context including contracts, tariffs, products, consumption, and up-selling opportunities.

                                                       

Watch the video

 

The Need to Reinvent Customer Service with AI

With market deregulation and the rise of prosumers, customers who generate their own renewable energy through Distributed Energy Resources (DERs) and sell it back to the grid, the utilities sector now faces significant challenges. The number of customer interactions form different channels are increasing and become more complex, with many options for different rates and products available to customers. This has led to increasing customer interactions and rising service costs for utilities.

One of the best examples of how AI can improve utilities business is with AI-driven tools, such as intelligent chatbots and virtual assistants, to provide personalized customer interactions and improve customer service. Many utilities still rely on traditional chatbots that follow rigid, predefined scripts, leading to inflexible and often unsatisfactory experiences. While these chatbots may suffice for basic tasks, Generative AI has the potential to revolutionize self-service capabilities.

These AI systems can analyze real-time data to offer insights into energy consumption, helping customers make informed decisions and manage their usage more effectively. This capability addresses operational challenges for utilities needing to explore new revenue streams and drive operational excellence.

 

Introducing the SAP Utilities Customer Self-Service Agent

SAP has announced a new Utilities Customer Self-Service Agent for its SAP S/4HANA Utilities Private Cloud Private Edition, giving utility companies the ability to address end-customers' needs through human-like and effective interactions while significantly reducing operational costs. They can use this capability to provide the same level of customer satisfaction as human agents while delivering superior performance compared to traditional self-service portals.

The agent is woven into the fabric of SAP's Utilities transactions, processes, and data, ensuring a highly tailored customer experience with full understanding of customer context including contracts, tariffs, products, consumption, events, and up-selling opportunities. The functionality features out-of-the-box integration to the SAP S/4HANA Utilities solution, resulting in lower implementation costs compared to other chatbot solutions.

Traditional customer service approaches can be costly and may not provide the personalized experience customers expect. The embedded AI-powered agent helps utilities avoid these issues by providing significantly faster response times, complete availability in any language, and reduced calls to contact centers while maintaining customer satisfaction levels on par with human agents and reducing cost-to-serve.

(Shown Demo UI not part of actual product)

 

Initial Release Capabilities and Planned Roadmap

In release 1, the agent comprises an initial set of self-service capabilities that utilities can provide to end-customers and which will be complemented by more features in subsequent deliveries.

Features:

This initial set comprises the capability to:

  • View Consumption:  view the consumption down to the level of individual billing periods
  • View Invoice: view the most recent invoice as well as any other available invoice for each contract account.
  • View Account Balance: end-customers can see their total account balance and balances for each contract account, including details
  • View Payment Information: access payment information such as bank accounts and payment cards.
  • Submit Meter Readings: they can submit meter readings for any of their contracts.
  • Move-In (Known User): move-in feature allows end-customer to conduct Move-ins into new premises by selecting available tariffs or services at the respective locations.
  • Switch Supplier (Known User): customers can also switch supplier by transferring their contract to the new utilities company and choosing tariffs that match their requirements.
  • Switch Tariffs: customers can also switch their tariff.
  • Explain Company: can ask questions about the utilities company and receive information in PDF documents using Retrieval-Based Augmentation (RAG).
  • Rule-based tariff recommendations are available based on keywords defined by the utilities company.

Each of the mentioned features can be individually turned on and off. Currently only known user access is supported. Additionally end-customers can switch between languages based on the language selection that the utility company decided to offer based on the underlying Large Language Model (at the moment GPT-4o) capabilities

 

How Does It Works?

The Utilities Customer Self-Service Agent is offered as API-only SAP-managed SaaS BTP application that entitled utilities can activate in SAP for Me.

After setting up the connectivity to the backend SAP S/4HANA system and configuring the agent features, utility frontends can interact with the agent conversation OData API using natural language. Thereby an omnichannel user experience is enabled. The utility frontend provides the end-customer utterances or messages, and the responses alongside potential data structures are returned for display.

Onboarding Process:

Implementing the agent requires you to have a SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition, utilities 2023 FPS00 or higher system, with Multichannel Foundation for Utilities activated. Few agents make also use of the Utilities Product Integration Layer and create Sales Orders to trigger the subsequent backend processes.

On the BTP side, if you have the above-mentioned SAP S/4HANA entitlement, you will be able to activate the Utilities Customer Self-Service Agent in SAP for Me. Here, you will already be able to do the first configuration steps, like connecting the agent with your SAP S/4HANA backend and defining which of the agent features as well as the languages that you want to offer to your end-customers.

After this and authentication is set up as well, there may be some more configuration steps that need to be done in BTP’s Business Rules Service, such as defining the products that your Move-In and Switch Supplier features shall show and what data needs to be collected from your end-customer to initiate the respective backend processes, for instance.

After this, you are ready to go with the integration of the agent’s APIs into your frontends via which you want to expose the natural language interaction experience that the agent enables.

For more details, please go to the Administration Guide for Utilities Customer Self-Service Agent.

 

The Differentiating Factors

  • Human-like conversations: Customers interact naturally without rigid menus, covering the full self-service journey.
  • Built into SAP Utilities: Deep native integration provides full customer context, enabling personalized interactions across contracts, tariffs, consumption data, and tailored product offers.
  • Fast to value: Out-of-the-box integration means quicker deployment, lower implementation costs, and a seamless end-to-end experience.
  • Boost service efficiency: Faster response time with accurate answers and efficient handling of complex inquiries - driven by direct access to utility system data.
  • Experience that performs: Customer satisfaction comparable to human agents—at a fraction of the cost—and clearly superior to traditional self-service portals.

 

 

The realization of the Utilities Customer Self-Service Agent was a team effort. Special thanks to colleagues like Ralph Kuehne   from our Product Management team, who not aonly contributed significantly to shaping the solution and ensuring seamless integration with SAP Utilities processes, but also co-wrote this blog article.

This collaboration helped turn the vision of AI-powered customer service into a practical, high-performing solution for the industry.

The release of this AI agent set a great milestone for SAP and the next chapter of AI innovation in Utilities - and this is only the beginning!

entry.title: Re: Are You Ready for the Mandatory Shift to E-invoicing in Belgium?
entry.content:
Hello @TiagoRibeiro,

In reply to your questions, I can provide you with the following information:

- To implement the Peppol Exchange with S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, you must only implement scope item 78L.  Details can be found in the following link, Help Portal documentation.

Under Additional Information on SAP Document and Reporting Compliance, Cloud Edition | SAP Help Portal, you’ll see that Peppol is listed:

- For the exchange of electronic documents through Peppol in Belgium, the DRC 'flavor' of 'SAP Document and Reporting Compliance Cloud Edition' is applicable.  This is a full SaaS and consumes SAP's BTP.  This is different from the other DRC 'flavor' that is valid for countries like Italy or Portugal: 'SAP Document and Reporting Compliance with SAP Integration Suite', where the BTP from each SAP customer is used. 

I hope this clarifies things.

Best regards,

Linda

entry.title: Updating CV or Candidate Data Submitted via Agency Portal (Before Candidate Applies)
entry.content:
Hello,

I would like to clarify how this scenario should be handled in SAP SuccessFactors Recruiting.

We are working with external agencies that submit candidates via the Agency Portal. The agency submits a candidate to a job requisition, including candidate details and a CV. At this stage, the candidate has not applied themselves through the career site, and we are also not contacting the candidate directly yet.

If a recruiter later reviews the submission and identifies that some information is missing or that the CV needs to be updated, the recruiter asks the agency to obtain the updated information from the candidate.

However, in this situation, neither the recruiter nor the agency appears to be able to update or replace the CV (or other candidate data) within the same job requisition after the initial submission.

My questions are:

  • Is it technically possible for an agency to update or re-upload an updated CV for a candidate they have already submitted to a requisition?
  • If not, what is the recommended or standard process to manage such cases?
    • Should the agency withdraw and re-submit the candidate?
    • Should the recruiter manually update the candidate profile?
    • Or is there another best-practice approach recommended by SAP?

Thank you in advance for your guidance.

entry.title: Re: Multi‑Payee Scenario – REA2 Condition Type Not Determ...
entry.content:
Check the following:

1. Condition Type Group Configuration
Verify that REA2 is correctly assigned in the Condition Type Group for Accruals. Check if the Settlement Settings for your Condition Contract type allow accrual postings when Sold‑to and Bill‑to differ. Ensure the usage indicator for REA2 is active in the contract.

2. Table WCOCOF (Condition Contract Accrual Status)
Review entries for your contract in WCOCOF by looking at status fields (open, reversed, settled). Confirm whether the reversal flag is set prematurely. Compare with contracts where Sold‑to = Bill‑to to see differences.

3. Split Criteria in Billing
Check split criteria in billing document posting. If Sold‑to and Bill‑to are different, the system may split postings incorrectly. Validate partner functions and account determination settings. Ensure the billing document passes the right accrual information into WCOCOF.

4. Accounting Document Flow
Trace the FI document flow. Is the accrual posting created but not reversed? Or is reversal triggered but not updated in FI? Compare with VBO2 / settlement run logs to see if reversal logic is skipped.

5. Condition Contract Settings
Double‑check the Settlement calendar (dates may trigger reversal incorrectly). Accrual indicator in contract header. Condition usage assignment at contract level.
